TopicTitle: Is there anywhere that I can get stock textures and meshes?

Articles.Content:
If you mean from KSP, you'd need to open a .mu or other image file and a .mbm file. If you mean generally stock items online, there are several websites offering such things, but may not be suitable for KSP use. There are also apps which are good for making textures. You can use PS or Gimp or others to do textures. But for already made, the above applies.

Oops! That's .mu model file and .mbm or other image file.

Edited November 14, 2013 by Dispatcher
Oops!

I should have specified, I meant the stock parts from KSP, like the orange tank, mainsail engine, etc.

I vaguely know about mbm and mu files, can you tell me the difference between the two? It seems to me like mbm's hold the pictures, but I'm not sure what mu's do.
.mu is the model format, .mbm is the image/texture.

Being a newbie Modeler and Modder I found that if you download the .18 Demo version of KSP about 1/3 of the parts are in .DAE format and can be opened in Blender. You will have to First open the DAE file with note pad or some other text editor and scroll through the CFG data and remove anything referring to /diffuse and everything in between too diffuse/ start and finish of the diffuse lines. Just remove those and it should open in Blender. This is due to the original model being made in some other program like Mya or 3D Max and not in Blender. There are 3 engine models, lander leg, A couple tanks, SAS, and RCS unit..couple more.

On another note there is a nifty little plugin for Unity that will allow you to mass convert (or singles) MBM's to PNG's very useful if you simply want to change the look of your stock parts http://file.zeblote.com/?f=MBMConverter.zip

TurboSquid has some rocket models, but unfortunately they're way too high poly for video games, ranging from 200,000 to well over 1 million polygons, whereas games can generally load around 100,000 before crashing.

Taniwha's Blender .mu import/export add-on will allow you to import the new .mu models and .mbms directly into the aforementioned software. The advantage of this method over the other alternatives listed is that this will allow you to directly see how the UV maps for the meshes are laid out.
